As I've written elsewhere, CBAs should not be an obstacle for distance learning but instead can be an important tool to set forth the joint expectations of school districts and unions as they deliver instruction, whatever the format.

School districts and unions (16/25) also used the MOU to set forth virtual professional development expectations to address distance learning. This is an extremely important use of the MOU as CBAs often cap professional development hours and or specify delivery methods.
That means the bulk of urban districts either had informal agreements with labor to set aside CBA provisions while moving to distance learning or simply ignored the contract in their rapid response.

What did we find? 25 percent of the 101 urban districts actually signed memorandums of understanding (MOUs) to amend collective bargaining agreements (CBA) to address distance learning in the spring (lower than I expected).

We set out to track collaborative negotiations between unions and school districts to address the move to distance learning in the spring in 101 of the largest urban school districts. We content analyzed social media pages, board meeting minutes, and district/union websites.

(15/) Teachers unions‚Äô resistance to reopening schools in a pandemic, and to participating in our poorly designed distance learning, makes sense. What doesn't make sense is to keep funding schools when our pandemic response is starved for public resources.

(12/) The state has reduced the number of instructional minutes (by an hour a day, for grades 4-12) and suspended assessments of student learning. Requirements for live instruction under distance learning are loose and hard to enforce. https://t.co/UUWe4pnu8t

(7/) The third major option, hybrid plans that the state and many districts are promoting, could be even more disastrous. These hybrids fuse all the problematic aspects of in-person and distance learning into unmanageable messes, with kids on campus some days and not others.

(6/) Many kids lack the technology and resources to participate in virtual schooling. Worse distance learning forces parents and other family to serve as in-home educators, adding stress for people fighting to hold onto jobs, or look for new ones

(5/) Distance learning‚Äîwhich is how many school districts must start the year under state guidelines‚Äîis unlikely to produce real learning. State officials and teachers‚Äô unions have imposed limits that rob online instruction of any potential value.

(3/) All 3 strategies on the table‚Äîthe full reopening of schools, a shift to distance learning, or a hybrid of in-person and online education‚Äîthreaten to weaken the educational system and leave our children further behind. https://t.co/HwhEIwc0lZ

Anyway, thanks to anyone who made it through my rambling thread of random thoughts. Writing helps my brain sort things out a bit!

The TL;DR of this is basically:
- Teachers are awesome.
- Distance learning is tough.
- We gotta help however we can!
- Also, mental health & #SpEd!

That's the part that keeps me going. The sense of community.

Distance learning involves less direct socializing (which is helpful for my brain). And it requires some outside-the-box thinking and on-the-fly problem solving, which I'm good at. It's good to know I'm helping people!
